title: 115_s1544
content:
The Act titled "No Funds for Cyber Coordination with Russia Act of 2017" includes sections on short title, definitions, purpose, findings, funding prohibition, sense of Congress, and termination. Definitions are provided in Section 2. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "cybersecurity" is defined in the Act. Cybersecurity is the protection of cyberspace from cyberattacks. A cybersecurity unit is an organization for cybersecurity. Cyberspace is the global domain of information systems. Significant activities undermining cybersecurity include efforts to disrupt information and communications. The curr_chunk discusses unauthorized actions related to information and communications technology systems, including conducting influence operations and causing misappropriation of funds for commercial gain. It also mentions significant destructive malware attacks. The curr_chunk mentions significant denial of service activities. The Act aims to protect US cybersecurity and critical infrastructure by prohibiting the President from establishing a cybersecurity unit with the Russian Federation, a known foreign adversary. Congress found that in 2016, Russian President Putin ordered an influence campaign to undermine the US democratic process, denigrate Secretary Clinton, and harm public faith in the election. In 2016, Russian President Putin ordered an influence campaign to undermine the US democratic process and denigrate Secretary Clinton. President Obama issued Executive Order 13757 to address malicious cyber-enabled activities. The Government of the Russian Federation has launched cyber-attacks against US agencies, leading to the imposition of sanctions under Executive Order 13757. These attacks targeted the Department of State, Department of Defense, and the White House computer networks. On March 15, 2017, the Department of Justice charged individuals responsible for these cyber-attacks. On March 15, 2017, the Department of Justice charged Russian FSB officers and coconspirators for hacking Yahoo and US citizens' email accounts. Former Director of National Intelligence James Clapper testified about Russia's influence in the 2016 election, stating it was their most successful effort to disrupt elections since the 1960s. Former FBI Director James Comey testified that the Russian government used various methods to influence American thinking, voting, and actions, aiming to undermine the credibility of the United States. Comey emphasized the seriousness of this threat to the democratic political system. President Donald Trump denied Russian meddling in the election and proposed forming a Cyber Security unit with Putin to prevent hacking and negative interference. Funding for a cybersecurity unit with the Russian Federation is prohibited using Federal funds. Congress expresses its stance on the matter. Congress believes the President should acknowledge Russian interference in the 2016 election, avoid cyber coordination with Russia, and establish an independent commission to investigate Russian cyber operations. SEC. 7. TERMINATION.

The prohibitions under this Act will end when the President certifies to Congress that Russia has stopped undermining democracies worldwide and admits to interfering in the 2016 US election.
